thread.title_full: Consumers slow to adopt newest safety features | Business News | ArcaMax Publishing

author: arcamax.com
title: Consumers slow to adopt newest safety features | Business News
text:
Existing technologies already available on new vehicles could prevent about one-third of the traffic deaths annually in the U.S., and save a quarter-trillion dollars, but consumers are very slow to pay the current price for these features, based on a study released this week by the Boston Consulting Group and the Motor & Equipment Manufacturers Association.
The report, outlined by Xavier Mosquet, BCG senior partner, tries to measure the savings from crashes and injuries avoided, lost productivity and other benefits the new safety features can deliver.
For example:
Crashes, of which there were 6.07 million in the U.S. last year, cost the economy $910 billion, or $4,000 per vehicle.
Broader adoption of such features as forward collision warning, blind-spot detection, night vision, lane departure warnings and adaptive front lighting could cut that cost by $251 billion.
The dilemma is that consumers are very slowly choosing them. So far only 7 percent of new vehicles moving off dealers' lots have forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control or automatic emergency braking.
The penetration rate on blind-spot detection is only 4 percent; lane departure warning/lane keep assist, 7 percent; adaptive front lighting. 4 percent and on night vision, only a minuscule 0.2 percent, mostly luxury cars, have it.
"Market dynamics will not be enough to drive these adoption rates up fast enough," Mosquet said.
The study suggests several incentives for consumers to seek out these features, including tax credits. Another idea is to offer automakers credits they can apply to the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards as they sell more safety features.
The problem is consumers aren't willing to pay what it costs manufacturers and suppliers to install these features.
For example, a recent survey found most car owners would be willing to pay between $100 and $400 for blind-spot detection, but the current cost is about $595.
One obvious way to accelerate adoption is for the government to mandate them, as it has done with rearview cameras, which must be installed in all new vehicles by 2018. The benefit of mandates is that wider adoption drives down the cost. The average cost of a rearview camera system has dropped from $722 per vehicle in 2010 to $550 today. BCG estimates that by 2020 the average cost will fall to $418.
